docs.title: Configure Static IP on Ubuntu using Netplan
docs.text:
Netplan is the default network configuration tool in Ubuntu (from 17.10 onwards). It uses YAML-based configuration files to configure networking.

This guide explains how to configure a static IP address on Ubuntu using Netplan.

docs.title: Step 1: Identify Network Interface
docs.text:
First, list all network interfaces:

ip link show

Example output:

2: ens33: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 1500 qdisc fq_codel state UP mode DEFAULT group default qlen 1000

In this case, the interface is ens33.

docs.title: Step 2: Backup Current Netplan Configuration
docs.text:
Netplan configs are stored in /etc/netplan/. Backup the existing configuration file:

sudo cp /etc/netplan/01-netcfg.yaml /etc/netplan/01-netcfg.yaml.bak

docs.title: Step 3: Edit Netplan Configuration
docs.text:
Open the config file:

sudo nano /etc/netplan/01-netcfg.yaml

Example static IP configuration:

network:
  version: 2
  renderer: networkd
  ethernets:
    ens33:
      dhcp4: no
      addresses:
        - 192.168.1.100/24
      gateway4: 192.168.1.1
      nameservers:
        addresses:
          - 8.8.8.8
          - 1.1.1.1
  • ens33 → Replace with your interface name.
  • 192.168.1.100/24 → Desired static IP and subnet.
  • 192.168.1.1 → Gateway address.
  • 8.8.8.8, 1.1.1.1 → DNS servers.

docs.title: Step 4: Apply Changes
docs.text:
After saving the file, apply configuration:

sudo netplan apply

docs.title: Step 5: Verify Configuration
docs.text:
Check assigned IP:

ip addr show ens33

Test internet connectivity:

ping -c 4 google.com

docs.title: Step 6: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
If the connection fails, try:

sudo netplan try

This allows rollback if configuration is invalid.

✅ Your Ubuntu server now has a static IP configured using Netplan!
